alerts.title: Trump preps for tariffs on Iran’s trading partners
alerts.body: Potential 25% tariffs on any country trading with Iran could trigger widespread trade friction.

alerts.title: Trump Threatens to Block Opening of Cross-Border Canadian Bridge
alerts.body: Potential blockage of a $4.8B US-Canada bridge could disrupt North American land trade.

alerts.title: Trump Tariffs Cost U.S. Households $1K Each in 2025
alerts.body: High effective tariff rates are increasing costs for US importers and consumers.

alerts.title: Commerce hits China, Vietnam with duties for molded fiber products
alerts.body: New US duties up to 540% on molded fiber products from China and Vietnam.

alerts.title: Falling Containers Briefly Halt Operations at Port of Rotterdam
alerts.body: Operational halt at a major global port due to container accidents.

alerts.title: Report: The Rocky Path to Stability for U.S. Retail in 2025
alerts.body: Tariff-induced uncertainty caused significant retail momentum loss in mid-2025.

alerts.title: Target cuts 500 roles, primarily in supply chain
alerts.body: Target is reducing supply chain headcount to standardize its operating model.

alerts.title: Logistics warehouse rents may rebound after 2025 drop: Prologis
alerts.body: Warehouse rental costs are expected to rise as demand from large retailers recovers.

alerts.title: The Upside of Tariffs: Why U.S. Manufacturing Is Entering a Rebuild Cycle
alerts.body: Tariffs are incentivizing a shift toward domestic U.S. manufacturing and reindustrialization.

alerts.title: US inks deal with Bangladesh to reduce tariffs
alerts.body: US-Bangladesh deal reduces apparel tariffs to 19%, easing trade barriers.

alerts.title: U.S. Cuts Tariffs on Bangladesh Goods, Exempts Some Apparel
alerts.body: Tariff exemptions for Bangladesh apparel using US materials lower costs for textile importers.

alerts.title: US, trading partners forge pacts to lock in critical minerals
alerts.body: US, EU, Japan, and Mexico signed pacts to secure critical mineral supply chains.

briefing:
• The threat of 25% secondary tariffs on Iran’s trading partners and potential blockages of critical US-Canada border infrastructure represent significant geopolitical risks that could disrupt established global trade routes and increase landed costs.
• A strategic alliance between the US, EU, Japan, and Mexico to secure critical mineral supply chains aims to stabilize the procurement of essential raw materials for the technology and energy sectors amidst rising global competition.
• Divergent trade policies are emerging as the US reduces tariffs on Bangladeshi apparel while simultaneously imposing massive duties of up to 540% on fiber products from China and Vietnam, forcing rapid shifts in sourcing strategies.
full_report:
## Critical Disruptions

The most significant threat to North American logistics stability is the recent executive signal regarding the Gordie Howe International Bridge. President Trump has threatened to block the opening of this critical infrastructure project, which serves the busiest trade corridor between the United States and Canada. Any delay or blockage of this crossing would severely constrain automotive and industrial supply chains that rely on just-in-time cross-border movements. Additionally, operations at the Port of Rotterdam experienced a temporary halt following a container collapse involving the vessel *Bangkok Express*. While the ship has since departed and no injuries were reported, the incident highlights ongoing safety and throughput risks at major European hubs.

## Ocean Freight & Port Operations

The maritime sector is facing a projected downturn in volume, with the Port Tracker report forecasting U.S. import declines throughout the first half of 2026. This softening demand coincides with persistent geopolitical volatility; Hapag-Lloyd reports that Red Sea diversions continue to impact freight rates and vessel schedules, forcing carriers to balance robust trade growth against significantly higher operational costs. In Northern Europe, the brief operational pause at Rotterdam serves as a reminder of the fragility of terminal efficiency during peak periods. Despite these headwinds, some carriers are finding opportunities in niche markets, though the overarching sentiment remains one of cautious capacity management as U.S. import levels normalize from 2025 highs.

## Air & Land Logistics

In land transport, the national diesel average has risen for the fourth consecutive week, reaching $3.688 per gallon. This sustained increase is placing renewed pressure on carrier margins, particularly for smaller operators where credit availability is becoming a primary determinant of survival. In the parcel and LTL sectors, major shifts are underway: FedEx and Advent International have reached a $9.2 billion agreement to acquire European parcel locker operator InPost, signaling a massive bet on last-mile infrastructure. Simultaneously, FedEx is moving toward increased automation by deploying autonomous trailer unloaders from Berkshire Grey. 

Labor relations remain a point of friction, as the Teamsters union has filed a lawsuit against UPS to block voluntary delivery driver buyouts. This occurs as Target announces the elimination of 500 roles, primarily within its supply chain division, reflecting a broader trend of corporate rightsizing. Meanwhile, the USPS continues to struggle financially, reporting a $1.3 billion net loss for the fiscal first quarter despite aggressive pushes into last-mile delivery services.

## Market & Economic Context

Trade policy remains the primary driver of market volatility. While the U.S. has moved to cut tariffs on certain apparel and textile goods from Bangladesh to provide relief for retailers, it has simultaneously imposed new duties on molded fiber products from China and Vietnam. The economic impact of protectionist policies is becoming clearer, with data indicating that 2025 tariffs cost the average U.S. household approximately $1,000. 

In industrial real estate, Prologis suggests that warehouse rents may begin to rebound following a 2025 slump, driven by large retailers like H-E-B expanding their footprint in strategic regions like North Texas. However, retail sales data shows a cooling trend, with December figures remaining essentially flat at 0.4% growth. This suggests that while manufacturers are entering a "rebuild cycle" due to domestic incentives, consumer demand remains fragile.

## Forward Outlook

Over the next 48 hours, supply chain managers must prioritize three areas:
1. **Cross-Border Contingency:** Monitor all communications regarding the Gordie Howe International Bridge. Firms with high exposure to the Detroit-Windsor corridor should begin auditing alternative routing via the Ambassador Bridge or Blue Water Bridge.
2. **Fuel Surcharge Adjustments:** With diesel prices trending upward for a month, logistics leads should verify that fuel surcharge triggers are accurately reflected in current carrier billing.
3. **Labor Monitoring:** Watch for developments in the UPS-Teamsters litigation, as a court ruling could set a precedent for how carriers manage headcount reductions and automation integration during the 2026 fiscal year.

tariffs.description: Economic Policy Uncertainty Index is at 259.1. Higher uncertainty often correlates with tariff volatility and trade barriers.
tariffs.calculation: Score = 100 - (Normalized Uncertainty). We track the Economic Policy Uncertainty Index. We normalize the current value against its 5-year range. Higher uncertainty = Lower Supply Chain Health Score.

geopolitical.description: Analyzed recent supply chain news. Found 2 high-severity and 5 medium-severity risk events affecting the score.
geopolitical.calculation: Score = 85 - (Total VADER Negativity). We start at 85 (perfect stability is rare). Each negative news article deducts points based on its severity (High = -8, Medium = -4). Historical trend is modeled using the VIX Volatility Index.

energy.description: Crude oil is trading at $64.25/barrel. Real-time pricing from futures markets.
energy.calculation: Score = 100 - (Normalized Price). We baseline the LIVE price against the 5-year historical range. Current price is positioned within the 5-year min-max range, then inverted (Higher Price = Lower Score).

shipping.description: Real-time shipping health derived from bunker fuel costs (Crude Oil $64.25) and market volatility (VIX 17.8).
